description: From Middle English lecture, lectour, letture, letteur, lettur, lectury, from Medieval Latin or Late Latin lectura (“reading”), from Latin lectus, past participle of legō (“I read, I recite”).

entries.meaning: A spoken lesson or exposition, usually delivered to a group.
examples: During class today the professor delivered an interesting lecture.

entries.meaning: (by extension) a class that primarily consists of a (weekly or other regularly held) lecture (as in sense 1) [usually at college or university]
examples: We will not have lecture tomorrow.
I really don't want you to give me a lecture about my bad eating habits.

verbs.description: lecture (third-person singular simple present lectures, present participle lecturing, simple past and past participle lectured)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To teach (somebody) by giving a speech on a given topic.
examples: The professor lectured to two classes this morning.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To preach, to berate, to scold.
examples: Emily's father lectured her about the importance of being home before midnight.
